source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: Fabrication of Zircaloy reactor components results in a marked preferred crystallographic orientation

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: tubing was in the stress-relieved condition, pressurized water reactor (PWR) type, with $1 0 . 9 2 \mathrm { - m m }$ diameter and $0 . 6 3 5 { \cdot } \mathrm { m m }$ wall thickness

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: tubing was in the stress-relieved condition, pressurized water reactor (PWR) type, with $1 0 . 9 2 \mathrm { - m m }$ diameter and $0 . 6 3 5 { \cdot } \mathrm { m m }$ wall thickness

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: Round-robin participants were instructed to perform texture analysis at the mid-wall using their standard texture technique

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: all participants chose X-ray diffraction as their analytical tool

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: All participants used either the inverse or direct pole figure methods to obtain their results

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: The most common quantitative numbers used by the participants were the $f$ -parameters originally defined by Kearns

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: Texture coefficients $T _ { c \left( h k i l \right) }$ for the principal crystallographic planes in the three orthogonal directions of the tubing were also used as a base for comparisons

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: $I _ { \tt m a x }$ is the maximum times-random pole intensity and $\phi _ { \mathrm { m a x } }$ is the angular location of this maximum

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: $I _ { \tt m a x }$ is the maximum times-random pole intensity and $\phi _ { \mathrm { m a x } }$ is the angular location of this maximum

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk1
evidence_span: the relationship between the (0002) and {1010} $f$ parameters developed by Kelly and Watson [13], $f _ { ( 0 0 0 2 ) } + 2 f _ { \{ 1 0 \bar { 1 } 0 \} } = 1$

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: Seven participants prepared the radial-direction specimen to a mid-wall thickness by the method devised by Tenckhoff and Rittenhouse [14]. Using their method, the tubing wall is first thinned by machining, chemically thinned to the final thickness, cut to size, and flattened elastically.
process_step: machining, chemical thinning, cutting, elastic flattening

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: Other laboratories cut narrow axial sections and secured them adjacent to each other on a platen.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: Composite specimens for the longitudinal and tangential directions were prepared by stacking sections of tubing together.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: Only the A and L laboratories machined the tube inner diameter to match the outer diameter surface in preparing their composites.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: Composite specimens were in most cases mounted metallographically and ground through 600-grit silicon carbide paper and then either chemically polished or polished to a $6 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ finish using diamond paste.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk2

evidence_span: Three laboratories (B, C, M) performed back-reflection partial direct pole figure [14] analyses using only the radial-direction specimens.
test_type: back-reflection partial direct pole figure analysis

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: Laboratories K and J also used only the radial-direction specimen, but coupled the reflection and transmission methods [15] to achieve a complete pole figure.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk2
evidence_span: All remaining laboratories used the reflection [16] method utilizing three orthogonal specimens representing the radial, longitudinal, and tangential directions of the tube.

evidence_span: The procedure results in a $0 . 1 \mathrm { - m m }$ -thick specimen whose exposed surface is ${ \le } 0 . 0 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ from the midplane of the original tubing.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: The procedure results in a $0 . 1 \mathrm { - m m }$ -thick specimen whose exposed surface is ${ \le } 0 . 0 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ from the midplane of the original tubing.

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: For transmission specimens the surface area should be somewhat larger and the specimen thinned to ${ < } 0 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Counting times varied from 1 s per data point (Laboratory B) to $\bf { 2 0 ~ s }$ per data point (Laboratory C).

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: The relative standard counting error at random intensity or in those regions of the pole figure where the normalized intensity equals unity should be maintained at $s _ { c } \le 0 . 2$ .

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Holt and Wingar [17] illustrated that the loss of diffracted intensity with specimen inclination (the defocus condition) is caused by the increase in the diffraction beam peak width with increasing inclination, and that this increase is greater for a sharp peak (annealed material) than for a broad one (cold-worked material).

source_id: STP754-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_5th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Holt and Wingar [17] illustrated that the loss of diffracted intensity with specimen inclination (the defocus condition) is caused by the increase in the diffraction beam peak width with increasing inclination, and that this increase is greater for a sharp peak (annealed material) than for a broad one (cold-worked material).
